H-0005.2
HOUSE BILL 1015
State of Washington
69th Legislature
2025 Regular Session
ByRepresentatives Duerr, Ramel, Ryu, Berry, Reed, Fitzgibbon, Macri, Doglio, Simmons, Peterson, Pollet, Kloba, and Parshley
Prefiled 12/05/24.Read first time 01/13/25.Referred to Committee on Local Government.
AN ACT Relating to energy labeling of residential buildings; adding a new section to chapter 19.27A RCW; adding a new section to chapter 43.21F RCW; and creating a new section.
BE IT ENACTED BY THE LEGISLATURE OF THE STATE OF WASHINGTON:
NEW SECTION.  Sec. 1. The legislature finds that improving the energy efficiency of, and reducing greenhouse gas emissions from, existing residential buildings, including detached single-family homes, is critical to meeting the state's climate goals. The legislature further finds that making information about energy efficiency and greenhouse gas emissions available to homebuyers will help homebuyers make more informed decisions and that this information will cause the market to better value the efficiency and the greenhouse gas impacts of energy consumed in a home. The legislature further finds that home energy labeling programs using the home energy score model developed by the United States department of energy have proven to be effective in other states.
Therefore, the legislature intends to establish a method for energy labeling of existing residential buildings.
NEW SECTION.  Sec. 2. A new section is added to chapter 19.27A RCW to read as follows:
(1) Cities and counties may require that the owner of a single-family residence obtain and make available a home energy performance report before the residence may be publicly advertised for sale.
(2) If a city or county requires a home energy performance report pursuant to this section, the home energy audit must comply with the requirements of this section.
(3) In order to minimize the financial impacts on low-income home sellers associated with a requirement to obtain a home energy performance report, neither a city nor a county may require a home energy performance report until the city or county has first conducted an analysis of such financial impacts and adopted a program to mitigate such financial impacts, including the subsidization of the cost of home energy performance reports for low-income home sellers.
(4) A home energy performance report required by a city or county pursuant to this section must include the following information:
(a) A home energy score, using the methods developed by the United States department of energy;
(b) An estimate of the total annual energy used in the residence in retail units of energy by fuel;
(c) An estimate of the total monthly or annual cost of energy purchased for use in the residence in dollars, by fuel type, based on the current average annual retail residential energy price of the utility serving the covered building at the time of the report;
(d) At least one comparison home energy performance score that provides context for the range of potential scores;
(e) The identification of efficiency measures that may be installed directly by consumers;
(f) The amount of greenhouse gas emissions associated with the energy consumption of the residence, in tons per year by fuel type, with at least one comparison measure that provides context for the range of potential scores; and
(g) The identification of the most significant energy efficiency improvements with respect to the residence.
(5) A home energy performance report required by a city or county pursuant to this section must be prepared by a qualified home energy auditor certified by a qualification certification program approved by the United States department of energy.
(6) The format of a home energy performance report must comply with the home energy performance report format developed by the department of commerce pursuant to section 3 of this act.
NEW SECTION.  Sec. 3. A new section is added to chapter 43.21F RCW to read as follows:
By November 30, 2025, the department shall develop, maintain, and make available a standardized format for home energy performance reports prepared pursuant to section 2 of this act.
--- END ---
1015.summary:
Purpose

The purpose of this bill is to improve energy efficiency and reduce greenhouse gas emissions from existing residential buildings in Washington State. The bill aims to provide potential homebuyers with key information regarding the energy efficiency and environmental impact of homes, helping them make informed purchasing decisions. By establishing an energy labeling system modeled after successful programs in other states, the bill seeks to enhance the market's acknowledgment of energy consumption and its effects on the environment.

Key Provisions

Home Energy Performance Report

  • Cities and counties may require sellers of single-family residences to obtain and present a home energy performance report before the property can be publicly listed for sale.
  • The report must adhere to specific state-defined requirements.

Financial Impact Analysis

  • Before enforcing the home energy performance report requirement, cities and counties must analyze the potential financial impact on low-income homeowners and develop mitigation programs, including cost subsidies for these sellers.

Required Information in Report

  • The home energy performance report must include:
    • A home energy score based on U.S. Department of Energy methods.
    • An estimate of total annual energy consumption.
    • Estimated monthly or annual energy costs based on current utility rates.
    • At least one comparative energy performance score.
    • Identification of energy efficiency measures that homeowners can implement.
    • Total greenhouse gas emissions from energy use, with comparative measures for context.
    • Identification of significant potential energy efficiency improvements.

Qualified Auditors and Report Format

  • Reports must be prepared by qualified home energy auditors who are certified under a program endorsed by the U.S. Department of Energy.
  • The format of the home energy performance report must align with the format developed by the Washington State Department of Commerce.

Standardization Deadline

  • The Washington State Department of Commerce is tasked with developing and maintaining a standardized format for the home energy performance reports by November 30, 2025.

AN ACT Relating to energy labeling of residential buildings; adding a new section to chapter 19.27A RCW; adding a new section to chapter 43.21F RCW; and creating a new section.
BE IT ENACTED BY THE LEGISLATURE OF THE STATE OF WASHINGTON:
NEW SECTION.  Sec. 1. The legislature finds that improving the energy efficiency of, and reducing greenhouse gas emissions from, existing residential buildings, including detached single-family homes, is critical to meeting the state's climate goals. The legislature further finds that making information about energy efficiency and greenhouse gas emissions available to homebuyers will help homebuyers make more informed decisions and that this information will cause the market to better value the efficiency and the greenhouse gas impacts of energy consumed in a home. The legislature further finds that home energy labeling programs using the home energy score model developed by the United States department of energy have proven to be effective in other states.
Therefore, the legislature intends to establish a method for energy labeling of existing residential buildings.
NEW SECTION.  Sec. 2. A new section is added to chapter 19.27A RCW to read as follows:
(1) Cities and counties may require that the owner of a single-family detached dwelling unit, duplex, triplex, quadplex, cottage housing, townhouse, or attached accessory dwelling unit obtain and make available a home energy performance report before the residence may be publicly advertised for sale.
(2) An ordinance adopted by a city or county requiring home energy performance reports pursuant to subsection (1) of this section shall have an effective date one year after adoption.
(3) If a city or county requires a home energy performance report pursuant to this section, the home energy audit must comply with the requirements of this section.
(4) In order to minimize the financial impacts on low-income home sellers associated with a requirement to obtain a home energy performance report, neither a city nor a county may require a home energy performance report until the city or county has first conducted an analysis of such financial impacts and adopted a program to mitigate such financial impacts, including the subsidization of the cost of home energy performance reports for low-income home sellers.
(5) A home energy performance report required by a city or county pursuant to this section must include the following information:
(a) A home energy score, using the methods developed by the United States department of energy;
(b) An estimate of the total annual energy used in the residence in retail units of energy by fuel;
(c) An estimate of the total monthly or annual cost of energy purchased for use in the residence in dollars, by fuel type, based on the current average annual retail residential energy price of the utility serving the covered building at the time of the report;
(d) At least one comparison home energy performance score that provides context for the range of potential scores;
(e) The identification of efficiency measures that may be installed directly by consumers;
(f) The amount of greenhouse gas emissions associated with the energy consumption of the residence, in tons per year by fuel type, with at least one comparison measure that provides context for the range of potential scores; and
(g) The identification of the most significant energy efficiency improvements with respect to the residence.
(6) A home energy performance report required by a city or county pursuant to this section must be prepared by a qualified home energy auditor certified by a qualification certification program approved by the United States department of energy.
(7) The format of a home energy performance report must comply with the home energy performance report format developed by the department of commerce pursuant to section 3 of this act. Cities and counties may add additional criteria and information to the standard report format.
(8) A single home energy performance report may be obtained and replicated for buildings constructed within the same land division using identical design specifications with identical features including, but not limited to, floorplan, type and amount of insulation, windows, attic fans, heating and cooling systems, hot water heaters, and appliances.
(9) The home energy performance report is valid for eight years after the assessment date, provided that no changes to mechanical systems, building envelope, energy efficiency, or square footage in the home has occurred. For the purposes of this section, an assessment date is the date the assessment was completed.
NEW SECTION.  Sec. 3. A new section is added to chapter 43.21F RCW to read as follows:
By November 30, 2025, the department shall develop, maintain, and make available a standardized format for home energy performance reports prepared pursuant to section 2 of this act. The standardized format report must include space for cities and counties to add additional criteria and information if they desire.
--- END ---
1015-S.summary:
Purpose

The purpose of this bill is to improve the energy efficiency of existing residential buildings in Washington State and to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. It aims to provide homebuyers with comprehensive information about a home's energy efficiency and emissions, which will lead to more informed purchasing decisions. The bill establishes a method for energy labeling of homes, utilizing successful models from other states.

Key Provisions

Home Energy Performance Reports

  • Cities and counties may require owners of residential properties to obtain a home energy performance report before advertising the property for sale.
  • Such ordinances will take effect one year after adoption.
  • Homes must comply with specific requirements set for the energy audits in these reports.

Financial Considerations for Low-Income Sellers

  • Before implementing such a requirement, cities and counties must analyze the financial impact on low-income sellers and create measures to mitigate these impacts, such as subsidizing report costs.

Contents of Home Energy Performance Reports

  • Reports must include:
    • A home energy score based on the U.S. Department of Energy's methods.
    • An estimate of annual energy usage by fuel type.
    • Estimated monthly or annual energy costs by fuel type.
    • A comparison home energy performance score for context.
    • Recommendations for potential energy efficiency improvements.
    • Annual greenhouse gas emissions associated with the home’s energy consumption.
    • Details on the most impactful energy efficiency measures available.

Qualified Auditors and Report Validity

  • Reports must be prepared by certified home energy auditors approved by the U.S. Department of Energy.
  • Reports have a validity of eight years unless there are significant changes made to the home.

Standardized Reporting Format

  • By November 30, 2025, the relevant department will develop a standardized format for these reports that allows cities and counties to include additional criteria if desired.
